dataSourceAttribution.description: The NCBI Taxonomy database contains the names of all organisms that are represented in the Entrez genetic databases.
dataSourceAttribution.displayName: NCBI Taxonomy

contact.name: Bruce Birren
contact.institution: Whitehead Institute Center for Genome Research

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Neurospora crassa OR74A Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.summary: The approximately 40-megabase genome encodes about 10,000 protein-coding genes—more than twice as many as in the fission yeast Schizosaccharomyces pombe and only about 25% fewer than in the fruitfly Drosophila melanogaster
dataSourceAttribution.protocol:
The genome sequence was assembled from deep whole-genome shotgun (WGS) coverage obtained by paired-end sequencing from a variety of clone types.
Sequencing methods for all clone types are described at http://www-genome.wi.mit.edu/. The sequence was assembled using Arachne
dataSourceAttribution.description: N crassa draft genome was sequenced, annotated and reported by the Broad Institute in collaboration with the Neurospora research community.

contact.name: James W. Kronstad
contact.institution: The Michael Smith Laboratories, University of British Columbia

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Cryptococcus gattii R265 Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.summary: C. gattii was initially classified as a variety of C. neoformans but has recently been recognized as a separate species. These pathogens are responsible for infections in immunocompromised and immunocompetent hosts.
dataSourceAttribution.description: The Cryptococcus gattii sequence was assembled by Kronstad Lab at at the University of British Columbia.

contact.name: James W. Kronstad
contact.institution: The Michael Smith Laboratories, University of British Columbia

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Cryptococcus gattii WM276 Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.summary: C. gattii was initially classified as a variety of C. neoformans but has recently been recognized as a separate species. These pathogens are responsible for infections in immunocompromised and immunocompetent hosts.
dataSourceAttribution.description: The Cryptococcus gattii sequence was assembled by Kronstad Lab at at the University of British Columbia.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Cryptococcus neoformans B3501 Sequence and Annotation

contact.name: Richard Hyman

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Cryptococcus neoformans JEC21 Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.description: C neoformans JEC21 genome was annotated and submitted to Genbank by TIGR

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Saccharomyces cerevisiae Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.description: Saccharomyces Genome Database

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Neurospora discreta FGSC 8579 Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.description: The current draft release was submitted by John Taylor et al. from University of California, Berkeley. The gene models are predicted and functionally annotated using the JGI annotation pipeline

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Neurospora tetrasperma FGSC 2508 mat A Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.summary: N. tetrasperma is the only Neurospora species that employs a mating strategy that combines selfing with occasional outbreeding using a novel genetic system (pseudohomothallism) and provides a model for studying both the genomic and evolutionary consequences of asexuality and inbreeding.
dataSourceAttribution.description: Neurospora tetrasperma was sequenced and annotated at the JGI and the project has been submitted to Genbank under accession number AFBT00000000

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Aspergillus clavatus Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.description: The Aspergillus clavatus genome (strain NRRL1) has been sequenced by TIGR with funding provided by the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID).

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Aspergillus flavus NRRL3357 Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.description: The Aspergillus flavus genome was sequenced and annotated by William Nierman et al. from JCVI

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Aspergillus niger ATCC 1015 Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.description: Aspergillus niger ATCC 1015 annotaions was prepared by Hein Stam et al. from DSM, Netherlands

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Aspergillus nidulans FGSC A4 Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.description: The A nidulans genome was sequenced and annotated and submitted to the Genbank by the Broad institute.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Aspergillus fumigatus Af293 Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.description: The Aspergillus fumigatus Af293 genome was sequenced and annotated by William Nierman et al. from JCVI

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Aspergillus terreus NIH2624 Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.description: The Aspergillus terreus NIH2624 genome was sequenced and annotated by William Nierman et al. from JCVI

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Schizosaccharomyces pombe 972h- Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.description: Pombase, European Bioinformatics Institute(EBI)

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Sordaria macrospora k-hell Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.description: Draft sequence of the Sordaria macrospora genome was prepared and submitted to GenBank by Minou Nowrousian, Jason Stajich et al.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Cryptococcus neoformans H99 Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.description: C neoformans H99 genome was annotated and submitted to Genbank by Fred Dietrich et al., from the Duke University

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Candida albicans SC5314 Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.description: The C. albicans strain SC5314 genome sequence and diploid contig-level assembly by the Stanford Genome Technology Center

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Phytophthora genome sequences uncover evolutionary origins and mechanisms of pathogenesis
dataSourceAttribution.description: Draft genome sequences of Phytophthora sojae and P. ramorum assembled and annotated by JGI and VBI. Please cite Tyler et al. (2006) Science. 313, 1261-1266

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Phytophthora genome sequences uncover evolutionary origins and mechanisms of pathogenesis
dataSourceAttribution.description: Draft genome sequences of Phytophthora sojae and P. ramorum assembled and annotated by JGI and VBI. Please cite Tyler et al. (2006) Science. 313, 1261-1266

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Signatures of adaptation to obligate biotrophy in the Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis genome.
dataSourceAttribution.description: Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis genome sequenced and assembled at WashU genome center and Sainsbury lab and annotated at VBI. Please cite Baxter, Tripathy et. al Science(2010) Vol. 330 no. 6010 pp. 1549-1551

contact.name: Chad Nusbaum
contact.institution: Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02141, USA

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Genome sequence and analysis of the Irish potato famine pathogen Phytophthora infestans.
dataSourceAttribution.description: Phytophthora infestans genome sequences annotated at the Broad Institute. Please cite Haas and kamoun et al. Nature 461, 393-398.

contact.name: EDGAR HUITEMA
contact.institution: Division of Plant Science, College of Life Sciences, University of Dundee at JHI, Errol Road, Invergowrie, Dundee DD2 5DA, UK

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: The oomycete broad-host-range pathogen Phytophthora capsici.
dataSourceAttribution.description: Phytophthora capsici is a highly dynamic and destructive pathogen of vegetables. It attacks all cucurbits, pepper, tomato and eggplant, and, more recently, snap and lima beans. Genome sequences were assembled and annotated at the JGI.

contact.name: C Robin Buell
contact.institution: Department of Plant Biology, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824, USA

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Genome sequence of the necrotrophic plant pathogen Pythium ultimum reveals original pathogenicity mechanisms and effector repertoire.
dataSourceAttribution.description: Pythium ultimum is a ubiquitous oomycete plant pathogen responsible for a variety of diseases on a broad range of crop and ornamental species. Genome sequences were annotated at Michigan State University.Please cite Levesque et al. Genome Biol. 2010;11:R73.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: C.neoformans RNASeq - Wild Type, nrg1 KO, and nrg1 overexpression
dataSourceAttribution.description: Unpublished Cryptococcus neoformans var. grubii H99 data from Teresea O'Meara et al. from Alspaugh Lab at Duke University on Wild Type, nrg1 KO, and nrg1 overexpression.

contact.name: Tamara L. Doering
contact.institution: Washington University School of Medicine, St. Louis

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: C.neoformans - Transcriptome analysis of ada2Δ, nrg1Δ and cir1Δ and KN99Α
dataSourceAttribution.summary: Identify Cryptococcus neoformans genes based on Transcriptome analysis of ada2&Delta, nrg1&Delta and cir1&Delta and KN99&Alpha wildtype cells in capsule inducing and non-inducing conditions.
dataSourceAttribution.description: C.neoformans grubii H99 data from Brian Haynes et al. from Doering Lab at Washington University Medical School on ada2Δ, nrg1Δ and cir1Δ and KN99α wildtype expression.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Neurospora crassa OR74A Expression Data
dataSourceAttribution.summary: This study compared gene expression from 3 different time points in hyphal growth by cutting 1 cm strip of tissue from the hyphal tip (3hrs old), several cm back (5hrs old) and further back in the colony (20hrs old) in Neurospora crassa OR74A growing on VM media
dataSourceAttribution.description: Unpublished data from Stajich lab at UC Riverside representing 3 time points (3hrs, 5hr, and 20hrs) of hyphal growth on solid media for Neurospora crassa.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: N crassa population genomics
dataSourceAttribution.summary: This study uses a "reverse-ecology" population genomic approach to identify ecologically relevant phenotypes in organisms that are difficult to study in nature.
dataSourceAttribution.description: Neurospora crasss data from Christopher Ellison et al. from Taylor Lab at at UC Berkeley on whole-transcriptome sequencing of 48 individuals to identify SNPs

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: RNA-Seq Expression - C albicans Comprehensive Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.summary: Massively parallel high-throughput sequencing of cDNA was used to generate a high-resolution map of the C. albicans transcriptome under several different environmental conditions. The regions that are transcribed under the different conditions have been quantitatively determined and 635 novel transcriptionally active regions (TARs) and numerous novel introns have bben identified
dataSourceAttribution.protocol: Data has been generated for C. albicans (strain SC5314) grown under a total of nine different in vitro conditions. Using our data set of about 177 million mapped reads, we have significantly refined the primary annotations of the C. albicans genome by determining the position of transcripts in the genomes, including 602 newly identified transcripts for strain SC5314, and by identifying 41 new introns.
dataSourceAttribution.description: Candida albicans data from Michael Snyder et al. from Synder Lab at Stanford University on Comprehensive Annotation of the transcriptome of the human fugal pathogen Candida albicans using RNA-Seq

contact.name: Marc Buhler
contact.address: Friedrich Miescher Institute for Biomedical Research

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: RNA-Seq Expression - S pombe Dicer Protein
dataSourceAttribution.summary: Dicer proteins function in RNA interference (RNAi) pathways by generating small RNAs (sRNAs). The solution structure of the C-terminal domain of Schizosaccharomyces pombe Dicer (Dcr1) is reported here. The C-terminal domain of Dcr1 constitutes a novel regulatory module that might represent a potential target for therapeutic intervention with fungal diseases.
dataSourceAttribution.protocol: Small RNA libraries from total RNA isolations of wild-type, dcr1Delta, dcr1SHSS, and dcr1Deltaloop2 cells and subjected to high-throughput sequencing.
dataSourceAttribution.description: Schizosaccharomyces pombe data from Pierre Barraud, Marc Buhler et al. from ETH Zurich and FMI Basel on nuclear retention of fission yeast Dicer

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Microarray Expression - Expression profiling of saccharomyces cerevisiae s288c
dataSourceAttribution.summary: The following experiments from Spellman et. al. : (1) Pheromone synchronization time course, (2) Size-based synchronization time course (elutriation), (3) Cdc15-based synchronization time course, (4) Transcriptional response to the cyclins Cln3p and Clb2p. The following experiment is from Cho et. al. Cdc28-based synchronization time course
dataSourceAttribution.description: Saccharomyces cerevisiae cell cycle regulation microarray data

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: P. sojae expression during infection
dataSourceAttribution.summary: This study has 2 experimental replicates and each one has 4 biological replicates. The first replicate is from P. sojae mycelial tissue sample grown in media and the second replicate is from Soybean hypocotyls infected with P. sojae 3 dpi.
dataSourceAttribution.description: This study has 2 experimental replicates and each one has 4 biological replicates. The first replicate is from P. sojae mycelial tissue sample grown in media and the second replicate is from Soybean hypocotyls infected with P. sojae 3 dpi.

contact.name: Takao Kasuga
contact.institution: Crops Pathology and Genetics Research Unit, United States Department of Agricultural Research Service, Davis, California, United States of America

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Phytophthora ramorum transcript profiling during sporulation and V8 liquid medium and Tomato broth
dataSourceAttribution.summary: Phytophthora ramorum transcript profiling in zoospore, chlamydospore , V8 medium and tomato broth
dataSourceAttribution.description: Phytophthora ramorum transcript profiling in zoospore, chlamydospore , V8 m edium and tomato broth

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Signatures of adaptation to obligate biotrophy in the Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis genome.
dataSourceAttribution.description: Illumina sequencing was performed using RNA from four week old Arabidopsis Ws-2 eds1-1 leaves, highly colonized with Emoy2, at 7 days post-inoculation at 60% humidity to promote mycelial growth in the mesophyll over sporulation .
